results.title: The Bitter tea of General Yen
results.creator_credit: Frank Capra, Walter Wanger and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Idealistic American missionary Megan Davis (Barbara Stanwyck) braves the ravages of civil war in China to travel to Shanghai to wed Dr. Robert Strike (Gavin Gordon), the fiancee she hasn’t seen in three years. When Robert postpones the wedding to go and save a group of orphans stranded in the centre of a war zone, Megan demonstrates her devotion by accompanying him on his mission. After the last of the orphans are despatched to safety, Megan becomes separated from Robert, and is overcome by the panic-stricken crowds. She awakens to find herself on a military train, travelling to the Summer Palace of Chinese warlord General Yen (Nils Asther). Initially she is repulsed and frightened by both her alien surroundings and the Generals’ attempts to win her favour, and demands to be sent back to Shanghai. General Yen, however, finds himself fascinated by Megan’s feisty nature, and finds excuses not to send her back to her fiancee. Any chance of a relationship developing between the two is irrevocably destroyed when Yen’s mistress Mah-li (Toshia Mora) betrays both him and Megan, initiating a sequence of events which result in the downfall of the mighty General. Originally Columbia Pictures assigned this film to silent film director Herbert Brenon, with Frank Capra lobbying for and eventually winning the project after Brenon left the studio due to creative and financial differences. Controversial due to its principle theme of interracial romance, this moody, sensual production deviated from Capra’s usual filmic concerns with its touching yet dramatic depiction of doomed love, a factor which Capra allegedly hoped would earn him an Academy Award. The characterisation of the Chinese in this film seems quite racist by today’s standards, especially the casting of Swedish silent film star Nils Asther, in the title role, plus a fantasy sequence where a demonic General Yen menaces Megan in her bedroom. The controversy surrounding the potential romance between a Chinese man and an American woman saw the film being banned in some areas. “The Bitter Tea of General Yen” was adapted from Grace Zaring Stone’s 1930 romantic novel of the same name.

results.title: The Birthday present
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Film Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Johnson and friends”.
Johnson, a courageous pink elephant, leads his friends on a series of adventures. He is joined by Alfred, a leaky hot-water bottle, McDuff, a cheeky concertina, Diesel the dump truck and Squeaky the battered robot. The stories on this tape include: “The Birthday present”, “Playing games”, “Sharing”, “The Picnic”, “Windchimes” and “Cleaning day”.

results.title: The Birthday party
results.creator_credit: William Friedkin, Milton Subotsky, Max J Rosenberg and Palomar Pictures
results.brief_description: Screenplay written by Harold Pinter. In a shabby seaside English boarding house, a man’s inability to cope with his fears and guilt comes to the surface. At first, in typical Pinter style, the conversation is trivial and banal but deepens and erupts from the commonplace and comic into terror. Stars Robert Shaw, Patrick Magee and Dandy Nichols.

results.title: The Birth of the baroque
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The 17th century interiors of Protestant churches were filled with Baroque art. Congregations were brought to God through the richest and most dramatic use of religious imagery. The architecture, sculpture and painting of the Baroque were designed together, part of a total and individual whole. Vigorous movement embracing the entire facade is also a characteristic of Baroque architecture and Caravaggio is highlighted in this episode.

results.title: The Birth of Soviet cinema
results.creator_credit: Harold Mantell and Maxim Gorky Film Studio Moscow
results.brief_description: Examines the golden age of cinema in Russia in the 1920’s by presenting excerpts from masterworks of Eisenstein, Pudovkin and Dovzhenko by film critic Richard Schickel. Explains why the 1920’s was a productive time for cinema in general.

results.title: The Birth of New China = Kai Guo Da Dian
results.creator_credit: Xiao Guiyun, Li Qiankuan and Changchun Film Studio
results.brief_description:
This is a detailed retelling of the events leading up to and following the Communists’ triumph in the Chinese Civil War (1945-1949), from the perspective of the two leaders of the contending parties. Although there is a distinct agenda in the narrative, the film attempts to display an objective point of view, examining quite closely the human strengths and flaws of the leaders of both sides. While the film takes a distinct moral position, there is a distinct shift in narrative approach from films of the pre-Cultural Revolution period.

Jiang Kai-Shek, leader of the Kuomintang (Nationalist) party is shown to be a worthy adversary to Chairman Mao Zedong. The Nationalists have so far outgunned and outmanned the Communists. All the Reds have going for them is the support and respect of the common people, what Mao calls “the heart and soul of China”. Jiang ends up being defeated and flees to Taiwan, vowing to return and crush Mao.

On February 3, 1949, Communist army enters Beiping, where Mao gives his famous speech (the original footage is shown in part). Meanwhile, Jiang laments his defeat, explaining in hindsight how the Kuomintang overthrew itself. The sore point of the film for the Mainland Chinese is the so-called “stripping of wealth and treasures” from China, transporting them overseas to Taiwan. This was an epic operation, with shiploads of gold and cultural treasures being secretly transported to Taiwan over the final months of the war.
Celebrating the 40th Birthday of the People’s Republic of China (1949)
(3 stars: James Donald; June 10, 2011)

results.title: The Birth of Australia's golden age
results.brief_description: A history of the Australian gold rushes of the nineteenth century, which shows historical paintings and views of still extant gold mining towns. Demonstrates the various methods of extracting gold Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: The Birth of a theory
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Addresses some controversial geological theories including the theories of Continental Drift and Plate Tectonics. It was only in the middle of the 20th Century that scientists accepted that the major continents were once joined and then drifted apart due to the geological activity occuring on and beneath the Earth’s surface. The study of the ocean floor provided valuable evidence which enabled the theory to eventually gain popular support.

results.title: The Birth of a nation [DVD]
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith, Harry E Aitken, D W Griffith Productions and Epoch Producing Corporation
results.brief_description: This 1915 epic American Civil War drama, using the interwoven stories of two families - one Southern and one Northern - is one of the most influential films in the history of cinema and, because of its racism, one of the most controversial. Based on the Rev. Thomas Dixon’s deliriously racist “The Clansman”, a melodramatic novel about the American Civil War and it’s aftermath, Griffith’s film is remarkable, for it’s technical innovations and for the truly epic feel created by the carefully orchestrated, swirling masses of figures in the battle scenes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: D.W. Griffith, Harry E Aitken, D W Griffith Productions and Epoch Producing Corporation
results.description: This 1915 epic American Civil War drama, using the interwoven stories of two families - one Southern and one Northern - is one of the most influential films in the history of cinema and, because of its racism, one of the most controversial. Based on the Rev. Thomas Dixon’s deliriously racist “The Clansman”, a melodramatic novel about the American Civil War and it’s aftermath, Griffith’s film is remarkable, for it’s technical innovations and for the truly epic feel created by the carefully orchestrated, swirling masses of figures in the battle scenes.
